text.author: Stephen Dubner
text.title: Multitasking Doesn’t Work. So Why Do We Keep Trying?
text.summary1: (human1) The interviewer asks Strayer, a cognition researcher, about multitasking, focusing on how dual-task interference makes it difficult (even when one or more of the activities is rote), how dangerous it can be (while driving or in medical settings), and how, contrary to popular belief, it causes a net loss of performance since it splits your attention.
text.summary2: (claude-3-5-sonnet-20241022) Dr. David Strayer's research at the Applied Cognition Laboratory shows that multitasking impairs performance across various settings, from driving while using phones to workplace productivity, as the brain struggles to effectively divide attention between simultaneous cognitive tasks.
text.summary3: (gpt4o) In this discussion, Strayer explains how multitasking often leads to decreased performance and productivity, using examples from driving and office work, and emphasizes that focusing on single tasks can mitigate these effects and enhance overall efficiency.
text.summary4: (Meta-Llama-3-8B-Instruct) Researchers at the Applied Cognition Laboratory in Salt Lake City study multitasking and its effects on productivity, finding that attempting to do multiple tasks simultaneously can lead to errors and decreased performance, even for simple tasks like walking and talking.
text.summary5: (Qwen2.5-7B-Instruct) Multitasking often leads to decreased performance across all tasks involved, particularly in high-stakes situations such as driving or medical procedures, due to competing demands on cognitive resources, while workplace multitasking results in reduced productivity as attention shifts between various software and platforms throughout the day.
